player_decision.reason: Open-raise Q9o in a 3-handed game to seize the initiative and attempt to steal the blinds with a small, standard raise while preserving stack depth for later play.
Fold: weak holding (6h7h) in SB facing a 20 bet in a 3-handed pot. Out of position with no strong equity or backdoor prospects, so preserving stack for better spots is best.
Getting a very good price in the big blind versus a min-raise; T2 suited defends well enough and plays fine postflop. Keep pot small OOP.
Out of position versus the preflop raiser on J-9-2 with just bottom pair and little equity; standard to check and keep the pot small.

Flop gives me middle pair (9s with 9d on board). Calling the small bet controls the pot, gets value from worse hands/draws, and avoids committing more against likely better hands (Jx) without improving.
Check. We have a weak pair (2s) on a paired board OOP vs the preflop raiser; leading doesn’t get called by worse often and risks a raise. Keep pot small and re-evaluate if he bets.

I have trip 9s (9s on board + my 9), a very strong but not invulnerable hand (beats most holdings but can lose to J9, 99, JJ). Alice has been calling passively, so a medium value bet should extract calls from worse hands and protect against draws without risking my entire stack. Betting 35 builds the pot while avoiding an unnecessary all-in.

We have two pair (9s and 2s) on a paired board. Villain’s large turn bet after flop check-back is polarized to Jx/9x and diamond draws. Raising commits us against better hands; calling keeps bluffs/draws in at good price and controls variance with him nearly all-in. Reevaluate on river, folding on diamond/very bad overcards.
Board is double-paired and the river improves Jx/9x to full houses; our T kicker has some showdown value but won’t get called by worse. Check and realize equity.

Board is 9-9-J-J-2 and my hand 9s Qd makes a full house (9s full of J). Very strong; only hands that beat me are Jx (or quads). Shoving maximizes value and fold equity for the 115 pot with my remaining 40.

Board is double-paired and the flush completes. Our hand is just JJ99 with T kicker—loses to any J/9/flush and is outkicked by A/K/Q. Villain’s turn bet + river shove is value-heavy; not enough bluffs for the price.
